Opportunity Cost (Journaling Exercise)

Michal Korzonek | July 30, 2021

There‚Äôs a difficult decision ahead of you, and you‚Äôre not sure which path to take.¬†

You‚Äôve probably already considered the pros and cons of each alternative, but in this journaling exercise we‚Äôll look at your decision through a different lens: opportunity cost. That‚Äôs because every choice has a hidden price: not benefiting from the alternative choices.

You can think about it as protecting space.

Every decision you make takes ‚Äúspace‚Äù (eg. your time, energy, money), leaving less space for other things in your life. Depending on the space required for a particular alternative, it might be more effective to say ‚Äúno‚Äù just to protect the space for other more important things that can emerge.

In other words, by saying yes to an opportunity, you‚Äôre simultaneously saying ‚Äúno‚Äù to alternative choices. And identifying the thing you would rather not miss out on can often be the best way to point you towards the right decision to make.

Exercise Instructions

The exercise takes around 15 minutes. All you need is a journal and a pen.

Note: You can also implement your subconscious processing to boost this exercise, by skipping the final step, and only engaging in it first thing in the morning on the following day (similar to the Most Important Question).

You can either journal along with the video I made for you (12m), or do it in your own time.

One important caveat: this exercise works best for considering a single option. If you‚Äôre torn between more options (eg. option A and B), then use the exercise for one of them, and if you don‚Äôt reach a conclusion by the end of the exercise you can run it again for another option.

Here‚Äôs how it works:

  1. Moment of grounding (1m), to transition mindfully into the exercise (eg. 10 conscious breaths, or meditative drawing

  2. Journal setup and stating the decision (1m)

  3. Journal: If I choose this option, what am I missing out on?* (3m)

  4. Journal: If I don‚Äôt choose this option, what am I missing out on?* (3m)

  5. Journal: What does my heart really want?* (3m)

  6. Journal: What is my decision? (optionally leave overnight and write first thing in the morning) (1m)

Questions and Insights

Here are some things that came up for my in a recent decision I made:

  • While it seemed like a simple decision, it actually runs much deeper than I thought.
  • Thinking about what my heart really wants makes the decision quite clear to me, even if I wasn‚Äôt sure what to pick before the exercise.
  • Reflecting on what I would be missing out on helped me understand what are my priorities
